Muss hier auch mal ne Lanze f√ºr die Mitarbeiter der Vietnamesischen Botschaft brechen. Habe meinen Reisepass am Montag losgeschickt (DHL Expressversand da ich die Geb√ºhr in bar beigelegt habe) und schon am Samstag kam der Pass mit eingeklebtem Visum zur√ºck. Die Geb√ºhr war mit 65 ‚Ç¨ (3 Monate/single entry, stand Januar 2016) zwar nicht ganz billig aber immernoch billiger als z.B. ein U.S. Visum und auch vom b√ºrokratischen Aufwand her deutlich angenehmer. Einziger Makel war der Umstand dass die Telefonnummer unter der man die aktuellen Visageb√ºhren erfragen muss dauernd besetzt war.

Mein Freund und ich brauchten ein Touristenvisum f√ºr 30 Tage mit einmaliger Einreise. Wir waren durch die Bewertungen sehr verunsichert.

Ich habe meine Unterlagen (Reisepass + Bargeld) pers√∂nlich in den Briefkasten geworfen, da ich gerade in Berlin war. Sonntag eingeworfen. Mittwoch war der Pass inkl. eingeklebtes Visum in meinem Briefkasten. Ging super schnell und es gab keine Probleme.

Die gleichen Unterlagen f√ºr meinen Freund haben wir etwas sp√§ter per Einschreiben geschickt (inkl. Bargeld). Samstag versandt und den darauffolgenden Samstag wieder zur√ºck gehabt. Auch hier alles einwandfrei.

Kann mich den Bewertungen weiter unten ebenfalls nicht anschlie√üen.
Die Botschaftsmitarbeiter sind weder faul noch korrupt, meine Angelegenheiten wurden immer z√ºgig und korrekt bearbeitet.
Und wenn man bei Organisationen wie Studentenverbindungen, Kirchen, Freimaurern etc hinter die Kulissen schaut, kann man absolut nicht nachvollziehen wieso Deutschland und viele andere Staaten der westlichen Welt bei Transparency International die vorderen Pl√§tze belegen...
Moment mal...
Transparency International ist ja auch in den westlichen Welt stationiert (Hauptsitz Berlin)...
Na so ein Zufall...

Ein Euphemismus f√ºr Korruption bei diesen Organisationen ist 'Protektionismus'...

Ich bin mit der vietnamesischen Botschaft in Berlin auf jeden Fall voll zufrieden.

Habe leider nichts positives zu sagen. Zocken ein ab wo es nur geht. Antrag wurde wieder zur√ºck geschickt, allerdings ohne Geld. Idioten! Ohne Kommentar. Keine Ahnung, wieso/weshalb/warum. War schon 2 Mal in Vietnam, aber ich habe die Nase voll ( das war nicht das erste Mal, wo die was versaut haben ). Die wollen nur dein Geld und der Rest ist scheiss egal ! Per E-mail bekommt man oft keine Antwort. Anrufen muss man dann. Oft aber kann man nichts verstehen. Sagen A und wenn das nicht mehr passt wieder sp√§ter B gesagt. Bin mir nicht sicher, ob die einfach nur dumm und inkompetent sind oder ob das Absicht ist. Andere Preise werden ein oft gesagt. Vermute mal, dass die sich den Differenzbetrag ( oder sogar alles ) in die eigene Tasche stecken.

Ich kann mich den ganzen Bewertungen hier nicht anschlie√üen. Vielleicht hatten wir aber auch nur gro√ües Gl√ºck. Zu unserer Erfahrung:
Sehr netter, gut englisch sprechender Vietnamese am Telefon der uns genau erkl√§rt hat was zu tun ist. Samstag den Eilbrief in die Post gegeben und am Freitag drauf waren die P√§sse wieder bei uns auf dem Tisch (5 Werktage). Wir sind zufrieden und ersparen uns das Warten in Vietnam am Flughafen mit allen Visa-On-Arrival Urlaubern, das war uns das Geld wert!
Future and Hope

reviews.text: Worst service ever, this embassy brings to concept or being rude to a whole different level. Applying for a South African visa is not easy to being with, but being send home a total of 5 times to change something yet again and being given incorrect information everytime makes this whole experience horrible. Staff is so rude, especially the man working there. If i didnt live in South Africa for year and did not need to visa so badly I would have saved myself the pain of going through this

The worst service you could ever imagine. Consular staff is beyond impolite and treats you in the worst way possible. Information is not given at all. I struggle to understand why they act in such a way and I have to say that the beautiful South Africa is represented here in a very bad way.

An experience I never want to repeat.

The facilities take me back to the 1980s.  Notifications stuck on doors, walls and windows with paper & sellotape.  Piles of papers and files stacked waste high on the floor.  Fingerprints taken with actual ink and ink pads.  The only building I noticed to have burglar bars.

The employees are unfriendly and unsympathetic.  Everybody seems to be wearing casual clothes; no uniforms.

The phone is not answered until 10h00 in the morning despite being "open" from 8h00.  Emergency number is not answered for almost 2 days.

They set a very bad impression in a country that is otherwise clean and professional.

Geen service " Helemaal niet " ze krijgen een dik salaris en nog kijken ze heel de dag sjagerijnig. 
"Wij hebben de ambassade nodig " het liefs spuig ik op ze net zoals all die mensen die daar nu in een rijtje staat te wachten zonder enige indicatie van wat er gaande is en moeten als idioten wachten. 
Ik heb een document opgestuurd, 3 maanden later wordt er in Den Haag en Zuid Afrika geen telefoon opgenomen. Nou ja, had iemand 1 keer aan de lijn toen vroeg hij om te wachten.. "achtergrond geluiden" meneer zit op zijn plek zit met collega's te lachen als idioten.. telefoon wordt gewoon neergelegd niemand die dat boeit daar want zij zijn Ambassade. jullie zijn schandalig slecht in Nederland en waar dan ook in de wereld. neem aub voorbeeld van UEA kun je nog wat leren betreft respect naar de mede mens toe wij zijn geen dieren, zet dat goed in jullie hoofd.

Borg kwijt omdat er in de kranten stond dat we hem moesten ophalen. 750 euro weg. Heb het bonnetje nog maar moest het ophalen toen ik nog in Zuid-Afrika was. Maar ga nu wel eventjes de kranten in Nederland in schakelen, want dit kan echt niet.

Its just radiculious applying visas from indian high commission ......poor staff,poor service and just waste of time. ....Australian government should take some serious action against staff....need to change indian staff to aussie staff....oreslse shut the consulate
Hi guys,i applied my student visa on 12 june ,2015 and i got visa on 10 august, 2015 no interview no enguiry,thanks high commision sorry,i put comment after long time.

Really slow process time and making excuses. My classes started two weeks ago and i still haven't got any visa. Worst of the worst possible. I cant describe in works about how frustrated and pissed i am with this embassy. The high commission should be relocated to some place else where people actually care and try their best to give visa on time.
Such a waste to call on the given no. And irresponsible staff..

Why you guys never pick up the phone.. 30_45 minutes on hold for oversea call is not a joke. Calling every day morning 10 to 11:30 & afternoon 2-3pm yet no one picks up... Come On guys, not only you guys are working on this earth... RESPECT TIME OF OHTERS AS WELL !!!! 

U GUYS DESERVE NO STAR ... MY ONE STAR MEANS USELESS AND DISASTER...

name: Embassy of the Republic of Serbia

reviews.text:
Avoid going to this consulate! 
I am a holder of green card and just moved in US. That trip was planned kinda quick. My spouse had to do a business trip to Europe. I wasn't  working yet and decided to go with him. 1st destination was Germany with 6 days in a country. Then 7 days in Switzerland. On a weekend we planned to visit France, coz it's only 15 min from a border town we supposed to stay in Switzerland. 

Not to mention my recent immigration paper work I did, all the prepared documents I brought were ideally done. I flew in early morning. In the consulate I had to deal with that female officer, an older woman in glasses. Been noticed she didn't like my Russian passport. She started acting all aggressive. Threw my documents and said to go to Swiss consulate. On my question WHY, her answer was: because I'm spending ONE day more in Switzerland than in Germany.. What a REASON! By rules for Schengen visa it's not right.. So I mentioned the followed rules, especially that Germany is being the country of my entering. But she just closed her window and left.
 I asked for her again, but she didn't come back and security told me to leave. I couldn't find my green card anywhere so I spent 10-15 min trying to find it. Then I told the guard about a problem so she called to officer. She said she doesn't have it. I've spend another 10 min reaching in my bag, in documents, on a floor, - everywhere!  And in the end it was in my marriage certificate somewhere between the pages (certificate has 10 more translated pages). While I was in this awkward situation, I've heard the guard, a tall african-american woman, was yelling on old woman in saree and a very young boy: PUT YOUR BAG ON A FLOOR, I TOLD ON A FLOOR! FLOOR! GO BACK! BACK! And many other LOAD orders. 

I had to leave, because I thought that guard will beat me lol. I didn't give up and started calling their phone service. I was on hold like FOREVER. They even cut me 2-3 times. Then finally somebody answered, I told the whole situation, but they cut me again. Then I tried and tried again, talked to somebody who didn't give me any clear answers. Just made everything worse. Told me to try in Swiss consulate. It's located only in a few cities in States and it's not easy to book an interview again and fly from another state (total price I paid for this trip $800 for plane tickets+200 for taxi cabs and Uber). Their minimum visa application time is 2 weeks ahead. I flew when it was 3 weeks earlier. So I didn't really had so much time and money. 

For Schengen visa you must go somewhere else! Very unprofessional, RACIST and disrespectful officer you might meet right there!!

I would have to agree with Qiang John who posted before me. I would give them a zero if possible. I been doing research on getting different types of visas for my situation (not going into detail). I started asking general questions about my situation to the Visa Information Person. My hopes was that she could give me helpful information to possibly pass on for my quest to get helpful answers, instead she rudely and disrespectfully told me all the information is on the website and you need to Contact your family in Germany to get that information from Germany and hung up. I called back and spoke to her supervisor in a respectful manner telling her how her employee acted toward me. Her supervisor started being rude and disrespectful towards me. They do not have any people-person skills and only want to deal with simple situations instead of trying to help and give information on complex situations.

Ive had good experience with the embassy today. They were very helpful and informative. I can't agree with the recent reviews, except that you have to go prepared with all the documents and fees. The officer in the embassy is strict but if you show her respect she returns it and is actually really nice! 
Definitely would go back again.

Knowing I'd need to travel in md-December 2015, I started gathering the required visa application documents in September.  I managed to get an interview date in November, only to find a sour and difficult woman at the visa window, who decided to take me on a whirlwind chase - rejected my employment letter dated September, claiming it was too old; twice rejected my insurance coverage even though it had specific amounts as suggested on the consulate's website, leaving me with no choice but to purchase more insurance from one of their preferred vendors; about a week before travel date she emailed me asking for specific pages on documents she'd accepted earlier without a problem....then she wanted to see local train tickets which I couldn't even purchase online....on and on.....she seemed to invent a project for me to work on every time I concluded one...  

The process at this consulate certainly proved to be one of the most inefficient, extremely frustrating, needless to say it cost me more time and money than was necessary.

Had a good experience here for my passport renewal. Security was professional, nice and helpful. Also the clerk was very nice and welcoming, friendly and helpful, the process was quick and painless. I came prepared thinking I had everything ready, however the passport pictures were in the wrong format (we're for American passports). So they sent me to a nearby Walgreens for new ones with 'German measures' (that Walgreens had the German format in their system). Came back after 15 minutes, everything was prepared and it took less than 5 minutes until all was done and I could leave. Be prepared for German hospitality which may seem not as friendly and joyful to other cultures (ever heard of German humor?) but we actually are. Most of the time!

I wanted to ask about the possibility to visit the beautiful Greece with a tourist visa as my Finnish resident permit is going to be expired (yes it sounds tricky) before I can make the trip to Greece as expected. It was a shame how a diplomatic staff can react in certain way. You lost a potential tourist and promoter for your tourism industry Greece!

Words cannot describe how incredibly shameful the service has been throughout my experience with the Philippine Consulate in Vancouver. Echoing many reviews here, they NEVER answer their phone, nor can you ever leave a message as the voice mail is always full. Initially, I was delighted to actually speak to a human being the first time I called, and not only was she rude, but she gave me a website address that did not exist, and then hung up on me when I asked for further information! The website for the consulate is also a mess with links that go nowhere...and even more amazing when I emailed them asking for a particular form as I could not find it on their website - someone sent me a response back with a link to their website. I doubt they even read the email. I would expect this indifference and borderline criminal behavior back in the Philippines where corruption runs rampant. But the fact that it is happening on Canadian soil is really quite shocking. I'm inclined to think the website is just a sham! Avoid at all costs!

What I express here is without prejudice and no disrespect to anyone but I am very disappointed with the staff there ‚Äì they know nothing about consular work.
They have no idea what I was talking about ‚Äì In fact they were asking me questions instead of answering my questions‚Ä¶
I went there to get a business / investor visa - I was talking to a lady in counter #7 in the afternoon on 17.May.2016.
End result: I have to go to some bureau in Manila during my next visit to the Philippines ‚Äì they cannot give me that visa here!
Not to mention they were disorderly, disorganized, and lack manners.
I need to inform president Rodrigo Duterte to either re-train the staff @ the Vancouver Filipino consulate or fire them & hire new staff who has some basic training.

I came to the Philippine Consulate Vancouver for Notarial Services.  I have to say that I was quite impressed with the services I received. I really enjoyed my experience at the Philippine Consulate.  The office itself is truly welcoming, clean, organized and comfortable.  Unfortunately, I forgot to get her name, but the lady behind the Notarial Services window (who also answered my email previously) was so warm, friendly, knowledgeable and highly professional. I received my package within two days.  They totally went above and beyond my expectations!  Kudos!!!

A consular outreach program was held last October in Victoria at the Phil. Bayanihan Community Centre. I drove 3 hours to get there to renew my passport. 

At the door was a woman who stopped me and asked me to pay $20 as a contribution to the Community Centre rent for the day. It was annoying, but I paid. Then I noticed that my name was No. 8 in her list. That was odd because the room was full of people. It was also after lunch, so what about all the people who came in the morning? Did a lot of them refuse to pay this unexpected "cover charge"?

Later, I found out that the Phil. Bayanihan Community Centre rents the room for $20/hr., so only 7 or 8 suckers like myself would have paid the entire day.  It must have been a very profitable day for them, extorting $20 from any Pinoy who showed up.

On the bright side, the Consulate staff in attendance were very professional and efficient. But the Consulate should find another venue next time and not be associated with the sleazy cash grab at the door.

Earlier today I arrived at your office at 4pm to have a copy of my passport authenticated. As I arrived, I took a ticket stub for window 6 (for authentication and notary services). My number was 53 and the digital screen showed 51. And so I patiently waited for it to turn 53 before approaching the window.

After 30 minutes, I noticed we were the only ones there. And so I approached the window and asked how come the digital display was never changed nor anyone call out clients when obviously there was no one left in the waiting room. While I was waiting patiently, there was no one being entertained and I even overheard them saying at around 4pm ‚ÄúHuwag muna kayo magsara. Kailangan natin ng pera.‚Äù Yes, very professional.

The excuse that the lady used was appalling. She said earlier there were lots people who were not taking tickets stubs or numbers and so she didn‚Äôt use it anymore. Did I get that right? Wouldn‚Äôt you need that system in place ESPECIALLY when there‚Äôs a lot of people, for order and efficiency? 

This is my first time to visit your office and my first time to ask for your services. I was definitely disappointed. I felt I was transported back to Manila with the inefficiencies of government offices there. I expected more. Why bother placing a queue system if you are not going to use it? I was just totally appalled at how your employees act. 30 minutes wasted because a lazy employee just refused to take any more clients at 4pm, when you‚Äôre suppose to close at 430pm.

I wish I would never have to use your services again. And if I do, I really pray that you improve it.

I was actually quite disappointed and extremely frustrated about the service as well as how I was treated. The internet states very clearly that the working hours are from 8am-4pm. I was at the embassy literally a minute before 12:30. A Phillapino lady answered the machine and was very rude and refused to let me in, saying they were closed at 12:30. She couldn't even answer a simple question that I needed information on. I had been phoning the embassy for the past hour before reaching the embassy and no one answered. Hence why I went there.  I don't understand why an earth they hire employees who are not even South African to work at a South African Embassy.

Some of the staff are incompetent and does not understand any questions. When you call them no one answers. When i asked about a visa for my husband this lady was unable to help me. I then asked for someone from south africa that actually knows the country and how it works. Then it was better. Why employ people that are not from south africa to work at our embassy. I find it super frustrating dealing with certain people at our embassy.

This is a South African Embassy , so there should be a South African employee to assist us. The website says that the Embassy is open from 8am - 4pm so they should update the website accordingly. I hope something can be done to improve the service.

 already been to the police station in Liverpool who stated they do not issue documents for lost passports due to the cuts and when we went to the police station in Birmingham they wouldn't issue one because it was lost in a different city. After calling the embassy before booking an appointment they stated that an affidavit just needs to be written and produced and that they'll except that. reviews.text: All the time and every time i have to go here I hate it, i get a feeling that i am going to leave all mad. They would never expect that from an American government agency but they expect it from the Mexican Consulate.  During every visit of mine with family members, we have been treated with dignity and respect.  They earned their 5 stars with me.  Very well deserved.

reviews.text:
Today I went to the Peruvian Consulate and found out to my grand surprised that the tiny little hole for waiting room had completely changed to a huge, well lighted, well ventilated, well decorated two huge waiting rooms. One of them a nursery for children. New front wellcome window counters where now we are able to see all the workers doing their job. behind a glass. They had up to date electronic ticket waiting machines and a screen TV. with news on it from Peru. Also the room was decorated with paint art made by peruvian artisans with Peruvian motives. I even got to meet the new Consul which greeted me personally and showed me how to use the new ticket machine. She was very pleased to see my excitement about the changes and told me that things were going to only improved seeking better treatment  for the Peruvian people seeking services from the Peruvian Embassy. I was very impressed by her sensitivity and enthusiasm.

I was told that the Embassy was under the direction of a new Consul, this was after the fact that I have meet her but at the moment I didn't have a clue that I was speaking personally with the Consul lol.  I would have never guessed because she was a very simple down to earth person. She spoke to me in a way that made me feel she was there to service me and not as person that for having that position was above me.

The service to request the document I needed was done super fast. Even though I showed up only half an hour before they closed their doors. Everyone was very pleasant, it is very obvious that the workers are fallowing the same gracious service attitude as the Consul herself showed me.

I am very happy to see all the wonderful changes and I am glad that we have a new Consul that really cares about her job and is doing everything that is in her power for the betterment of the treatment of the Peruvian population. It made me feel very proud to be Peruvian.

I personally like to give thanks to the new lady Consul for all her efforts and great job. Keep up the good work!
Thank you

Today I came to the Peruvian consulate to get my DNI, and while in the waiting room, we had to translate for foreigners who are trying to get a visa, because Mrs Miranda ( who was calling numbers and giving information) disregarded that these potential tourists are asking her questions in English and she was replying to them in Spanish, they had no idea what was going on, what number was being called, etc. would it make sense to assign a bilingual person to do this task?  On top of that, she asked for a document in deposit for the bathroom key to one of the ladies in the waiting room, after we saw that everyone else was getting the key without such requirement. When I inquired for the reason she asked this specific individual for an identity document, she had no reasonable answer, staying "it depends on the person"... What's up with that?, she is singling out an individual in the room and she explains this nonsense? Is it based on looks? Or What's the policy on this?. I felt really bad, me di√≥ verguenza ajena!
Yoo

Everyone there is really friendly and efficient.
It took me 40 mins to an hour to complete everything (including the waiting time)

Tips:

1. Although you are not allowed to bring any electronic devices (e.g., smartphones, wireless keys, or fitbits), upon arrival, you can keep your belongings in a lockbox provided by the consulate. I didn't know that I could do that, so I didn't bring my cellphone and asked my friend to wait in the front. Now that you know, feel free to bring them, but they have to fit in a small-size lock box (so no backpack).

2. Try to get the earliest appointment (i.e., 8AM) and go there 10-15 mins early. This way, you will be one of the first few people in line and get it done fast. I went there at exact 8AM, but my queue was already at number 26.

Being a consulate, I'm sure this place gets a bad rap for various reasons. However, overall I think the experience was about as good as the poor people who work here could've made it. On average, this place deals with over 300 people a day, and that's just the NIV applicants (not counting IV and citizen services).

First, the cons:
- The wait is indeed long. It is not "intentionally long" as some people are claiming in the reviews...that would just be silly. It's just that everyone has to be dealt with on a case-by-case basis, which takes time. I went in at 8:45 am and got out at 10:30 am. The actual visa approval took 2 minutes.

- They prohibit a whole lot of things, and if you have a backpack and walked there, they ask you to stow it at the coffee shop across the street. Which is actually quite convenient, but it would be more convenient if they informed you right away when they saw your backpack, rather than making you wait in line first.

The pros:
- Everyone was really nice and polite, especially Anthony at the fingerprinting station.

- Visa approval was quick and painless.

- Everything felt quite organized, it wasn't stressful.

Twenty fourth floor? big building adjoined to Weston Hotel with inconvenient but navigable new American security. Just explain that you need access to Russian Consulate and ask what floor and find the right elevator to that floor.  New (2012 after APEC conference) liberalized 3 year visas are a real time saver for multiple entry.  Familiarize yourself with the internet information as the office is very small and people very busy...so be prepared and have all documents, invitation letter if required.  For long term visas, AIDS tests are required but they are glad to send you down the street to public health testing center with simple oral swab test with immediate results and the required report.
Also, no cash or credit card payment; payment must be by postal money order, so once they give you the cost you then go across the street, west a half block to the US Post office to get a money order for exact amount..  Be careful to time it so you are there during the half day that is dedicated to public service hours.  If you are asked for interview, you will find they are very nice people in spite of being under time pressure.  Keep in mind that political problems all around the world are exacerbated by US State Dept.; Russia Ukraine relations are no exception.  Russia is a wonderful experience and great place for expats.
Always great service!!! A wonderful experience!!!! Russia is awesome and the consulate reflects this!!!

Then she asked "Was it so hard to answer?" I was shocked and appalled by the way she was speaking and the tone of her voice.  For someone who represents Russia and she was so rude and disrespectful.  When I asked for her name she said that she was calling from Russian Consulate.  Didn‚Äôt even bother to provide her name! It is so shameful that the level of service they provide is so inadequate. When I asked her what she wanted she just hung up on me.  I am shocked and sadden that this is how Russia and Russian people are represented here in Seattle.

I wrote a very negative review with only 1 star earlier in October (see below). 
But the embassy finally solved my problem really quickly. When we arrived at the embassy for our new emergency appointment, employees were all aware of our arrival, and we had a great welcome. Everything went really smooth.
I was impressed that my requests online were answered so quickly, and that I even received a call to fix a new appointment straight. 
Great job, thanks to all embassy personnel !

*************************
First review:

The consulate in itself is fine : staffs are welcoming and nice, and it's quite well organised.

But unfortunately for us (5 persons), they had a "small computer problem" preventing them accessing our online application...
And this is where all the problems started. 

I was simply advised by the visa officer to do the application online one more time (this time based in Melbourne), so that they can access it. And to make another appointment.
It sounded so simple.
I was OK for the 2 extra hours recreating our application online, but then it was impossible to make appointment online, since my profile had already one... And impossible to create a new profile.
We had to walk down the consulate again, explain briefly our situation to the man at the door, who gave us an email address.
I sent an email, and got an automatic answer, saying that this email was only for "immigrant visas" (not our case). 
But I eventually found a phone number...
Upon calling, and after some lengthy explanation, I was told that they have to mark our first appointment as a "show off" (I hate that, since we really came on time, and it has nothing to do with the problem), and we will receive an email within 24/48 hours. After then only will I be able to make a new appointment. Which, if I looked on the website, would be available after the 17 November !!! In 3 weeks !...
No need to say I will have to reschedule our flights and pay for this, book a hotel in Melbourne for 3 weeks (we are traveling in Australia and our next destination will be USA), and change all our plans.

This extra unforeseen waiting time and the extreme rigidity of their system is really frustrating. 
I really wished they could have just apologised for their computer problem, and simply book me the day after. It would have been so simple for everyone. And save us few hundreds, if not thousands, of dollars.

I also wished I could have sent a feedback to the consulate straight, via their website or an email address, rather than online here. But I saw nothing allowing me to do so.

My daughter just attended an urgent student visa appt and it was a terrible experience. The staff were really rude and I now have her in tears. She really wants to start her US Uni classes on time next week and despite the Consulate keeping all documents and making a payment that needed to be paid, she/we have  no idea what happens next. Such a shame this is her first exposure to what is supposed to be an exciting US opportunity to study overseas.

Everyone from the security staff to the office admin staff and officials were professional, friendly, helpful, and efficient. We had two young children getting tired and everyone was very kind and understanding. The caf√© downstairs was also great for a light lunch - staff were all lovely.

The overall opinion of the employee accepting the documents and her attitude was very bad.
- The applicant is asked to fill in the family member's names (just on spot, near the window), and nowhere is mentioned that the parents' names should be filled in even in case they are not alive.
- The employee refused to take property certificates of 2 lands, saying that the land is not considered to be a real estate.
- The employee asked for a certificate just of the apartment the applicant currently lived in, even after being informed that the person is not registered in that apartment. There is no such requirement in the required documents list, so the applicant didn't have that copy, which was considered as an omission.
- Later the applicant was given back the passport with refusal by the another employee, who told that the applicant is refused because of not enough financial state of the applicant's family member; but the required documents list does not require certificates of applicant's family's member's financial state.

Made an appointment, went there to apply for a Schengen visa, brought all necessary documents. The young lady at the main window called me up within 5 minutes of my arrival.

Even though her English wasn't that great, she had a really sweet personality and gave a vibe of "girl next door" home-grown German sweetness. Her shiny but understated lipstick was quite professional, and her barely-restrained big round boobs made everything even better as she innocently moseyed around making copies of things. They jiggled and heaved JUST enough to elicit daydreams. At one point she had to repeat a question because I was kinda "lost"... and I believe she knew EXACTLY why I was temporarily distracted, as evidenced by her slightly-smirky yet patient smile.

Anyway I got my stamped passport mailed back to me in about a week. Even though I didn't use that particular visa, this was a very positive experience overall.

My whole experience with this German Consulate was awesome. The whole procedure for my application took 14 weeks but all went smooth and special thanks to Mr. Armin Jurgens for his guidance and cooperation through all the procedure.

Neutral experience - for passport-related things, process is pretty straightforward and overall uneventful. A few things I found characteristically sobering:

1. Typical German bureaucracy: don't expect service with a smile (exception may be lobby reception). Don't be surprised if responses come wrapped with sentiments of annoyance of the sort "Didn't you read and fully understand our *entire* website with all of its 516 links and 8765 footnotes?"

2. Payment in USD but deducted from credit card in exchanged Euros: this incurs unfavorable exchange rates and fees. I brought Euros, hoping to avoid this problem, but to no success. Why charge in Euros but force a customer to pay with USD rolled into Euros? Utter office-chair-bureaucrat-farting nonsense!

3. Brought copies, because the website unambiguously stated so. But, not a single one needed. This opens the online info up for interpretation: what is needed? what is real? Wonderful!

Oh, and here's the kicker: appointment wait time for a regular passport was 6 weeks for me. I called to inquire about temp passport. Guess what: wait time is also 6 weeks! What's the point?

I applied for my passport here recently and things went very smoothly. I just have some heads-ups for anyone considering the same: 

1) Main entrance is on First Avenue. Entrance for passports, visas, and other legal matters is on 49th Street to the right of a barber shop, around the corner from the main entrance.

2) Despite what the consular web site says, expect to pay in dollars, not euros. I brought ‚Ç¨80 for nothing. 

3) It might be a good idea to get your passport photo taken at the consulate, as I did. Arrive early, go to the third floor and use the machine there.  It costs $5 and takes American dollars only in denominations of $1 or $5, but it appears to match Germany's passport specifications better than a typical American drugstore photo.

reviews.text: Volevo consigliare la dott.ssa Russo Stefania la quale ha tradotto alcuni atti di citazione e procura in lingua francese in modo ineccepibile preciso e puntuale.  La ricontatteremo nel futuro per altri nostri clienti.

Competenza, professionalit√†, esperienza, cortesia e tanta disponibilit√†, √® stato un piacere avvalersi della collaborazione della Dott.ssa Stefania Russo.....  un vero punto di riferimento nel settore!

Consiglierei di rivolgersi alla dottoressa Sfefania Russo a chiunque abbia necessit√† di tradurre dei documenti da produrre all'estero. Seriet√†, velocit√† ed una buona quota di simpatia sono tutte qualit√† che ho riscontrato nella sua persona. Nel mio caso avevo necessit√† di inviare con urgenza all'estero il mio diploma di laurea in inglese e la dottoressa si √® mostrata subito disponibile, consegnandomi il diploma tradotto in tempi record. Aggiungo inoltre un'altra qualit√† importantissima: l'onest√†. Esistono, infatti, vari tipi di traduzioni che richiedono all'estero ed ogni traduzione ha il suo costo. La dottoressa ha subito capito quale traduzione faceva al caso mio ed anzi ha fugato anche alcuni miei dubbi iniziali. Se avessi di nuovo bisogno di farmi tradurre dei documenti saprei di certo a chi rivolgermi. La consiglio!

Consiglio vivamente la Dottoressa Stefania Russo per le traduzioni giurate.
Seriet√†, professionalit√†, disponibilit√† e velocit√† garantite.
Ho contattato il suo studio per la traduzione di alcuni documenti per lavorare all'estero e sono stato pienamente soddisfatto del suo lavoro, aggiungo inoltre che si √® resa disponibile ad aiutarmi e a chiarire alcuni dubbi relativi alla mia partenza.

La Dottoressa Stefania Russo, e' una professionista seria, preparata e disponibile.
E'stata velocissima per la traduzione giurata di titoli universitari, sempre disponibile a tante mie domande, sono rimasto pienamente soddisfatto del suo operato.
Consiglio vivamente la Dr.Russo, sopratutto per velocit√† e professionalit√†.

Please update your site and voicemail and consider training your employees to not be so rude!

reviews.text:
I went to "Royal Thai Embassy" a few days ago to apply Visa. Since i'm a local businessmen staying at Myawady i need a Visa to go to Bangkok via Mae Sot. I needed to travel all night to come to Yangon. I've been to Thailand many times before and have good relationship with Thai companies and Thai people. 

The staff at Visa counters asked me for return tickets. I tried to explain them that i'm going via Mae Sot so i cannot show them valid tickets. They asked again for Yangon-Myawady-Yangon Bus tickets. I went to buy tickets and show them original and copy of tickets. They told me mine is fake, i asked them to call the bus station and enquire about it. They doesn't and kept telling me to bring the "real tickets". 

Someone was applying next counter with the fake tickets they just bought from black-market just outside of the Embassy and yet the staff accept it. Why is my real tickets are not accepted and fake ones are accepted ? Why illegal business is allowed just ouside of Embassy and why the staffs are accepting it ? 

Me and my cousins brothers are visiting Yangon-BaAn-MaeSot-Bangkok-Phuket-Yangon this holiday. So they need Visa, they are just kids so i prepared documents for them. During Thingyan holiday, no express Bus are pre-selling their tickets. I had to explain again to that woman at the Visa counter. My cousins have been to Thailand before so i thought they wouldn't need much documents. She can just scan the passport and see every detail in her computer. She wouldn't mind, she's busy with her phone using facebook ! Can you believe it ? "Royal Thai Embassy" should put some surveillance camera and check how your staffs are behaving. We're tourists. We're spending money on your country on purpose of leisure, not stealing. 

I have total respect and understading to Thailand's rule and regulations. It's not about the rule, it's the staffs especially that woman with brown skin, short height, some pimples on her face. I understand that is Embassy not Bureau of Investigation. Next time, I'd rather pay 10,000 ks to black-maketers outside of Embassy and have my Visa easily with fake documents because the staffs tend to think fake documents are real.

We had to get a Schengen visa for my wife and went downtown to the Italian Consulate for our appointment. This review applies to the lady in her 40‚Äôs 50‚Äôs who took care of our case.

From the moment the window opened and you heard the call out; you could tell this was not going to be a pleasant experience. My wife English is not perfect but she can communicate well - but the woman behind the window was so intimidating from the get go that my wife got nervous and I had to step in to help to save her. Improving the line of communication did not change the woman's attitude.

I would say that, given the fact that we were there on time, that we had all the supporting documentation and we were doing our best to be nice and polite and to answer every question (in spite of her terrible attitude) I find hard to justify why she had to scream every question at us... And most offending of all (beware of this), why the need to throw the papers back at us every single - for no reason? This single action throughout the whole process was the most disrespectful of all ‚Äì I was really trying to hold back not to say anything because I knew it would help the case. But this gesture alone shows she has no people skills, professionalism or any manners at all. 

Maybe at some point she said, ‚Äúyou‚Äôll love Italy‚Äù. That was one of very few positive statements throughout the whole time.

The only reason why she (because I can't speak for the rest of the staff) - the only reason why she is that way is because she chooses to. Like I said, our case was EASY, they even returned‚Ä¶ not wait‚Ä¶ ‚Äúthrew‚Äù some papers back at us because they had more than enough. It was so uncalled for...

Getting this simple visa was a very unpleasant and aggravating experience, unnecessarily!

A bit of customer service training (not just technical) will go a long way at the Chicago Italian Consulate.
Was there for only 30 minutes. La donna at the window was very pleasant. I received my visa in the mail 3 days after my appointment.

The guy at the reception booth is very nice, but one you go to see the woman in charge of helping you get your documents together for dual citizenship, make SURE she shuts up and listens to your questions! She'll talk over you and won't hear your entire question! I asked her 3 times if she was SURE that I needed to have my FATHER'S lineage's birth certificates as well as my MOTHER'S (my mother's line is the one that is Italian; NOT my father's).  She kept nodding and stating, "Your FATHER'S birth certificates!"  6 months later, after searching all the way back to my dad's grandfather, I went in with everything.  THEN she tells me that I didn't need my father's family's birth certificates!!!!! I looked at her like she was nuts and I said, "YOU TOLD ME TO GET MY FATHER'S PAPERS!"  She denied ever saying it and said she would never say that and she had been working there for 30 years! Time for retirement, I say.  I said to her, "Then WHY would I have gone through all the trouble if you hadn't told me to get it?!"  After that, she claimed that I didn't have my grandfather's papers on my mother's side and was ready to shuffle me away! I told her to look again in the paperwork! (she was behind a protective glass so I couldn't physically show her)  She shuffled through the paperwork again, FINALLY FOUND IT, then declared me a citizen...FINALLY! Four years of doing the paperwork mambo with these Einsteins was not fun, but when I want what I want, no one is going to stand in my way and that's the way you have to be with these people.  Be tough and tenacious.  When they realize they're not going to get rid of you until you get what you want, that's when they move their butts!
Giovanni was so incredibly kind and helpful!  He answered all of my questions and couldn't have been nicer.  Wonderful experience!

reviews.text: Extremely disappointed! I lost my passport so I needed to replace it. They make absolutely NO effort to be thorough or helpful to Canadians. They don't communicate; they don't give you the proper information; they waste your time.

I came yesterday to vote for the federal elections. I arrived a bit before the closing time and the guy refused to serve me without any further informations. So I came back today and then I've been told that I had to come back again because we can only vote from 9am to 12: which I can understand. But what annoyed me the most was that none of them were able to serve me in french, the official language of my province. Both times my experiences were negative. I am a young backpacking traveller and I think I was just not taken as seriously as anybody else would have, even if it was to fulfill my civic duty.

I was selected to install a fire alarm system here. While the job was not completed, the time I spent here was very intense, and all of the people I had the pleasure to work with, were professionals. The weather was extremely crazy. It is, after all Africa, so I knew it would be hot. 
Still, the work was eye-opening, and the security was nothing less than excellent, while on site.
The daily commute to and from our compound, was another story. The vehicles we had at the time, were less than reliable. On occasion, they left us stranded, and the streets are not safe. I had weapons pointed at me more times than I could recall, so I eventually left to return to the safety of my home in the USA.

There is never any answer on any of the three UK numbers that they have advertised on the website. The fourth number is actually for the Customer Support Centre in Romania from which you then get transferred to the UK number where there is never any answer. 
They take days to reply to emails. 
When you go into the Embassy, the staff are rude and expedient, displaying faces of boredom and annoyance (the clearly hate their job!). I suppose the constant chaos that exists there does not help make staff's life easier. They seriously need to implement a working system or hire more (competent) staff.
I rather travel to Romania to have things done than pay the high fees for a very poor service.

I  had an appointment with the Spanish Consulate on Thursday 2nd of June, which after reading the high number of negative reviews from other Spanish citizens and due to my situation of losing my passport, I  was dreading to go.  On arriving at the consulate, I  found 2 queues: one was for people registering to vote and another queue for people who made an arranged appointment like myself. They have one member of staff outside assisting and directing people. I  found him to be polite, calm and very helpful. The civil guard before entering the building was polite and friendly. The receptionist, the cashier and the lady who conducted my interview were all very professional, polite and efficient. The name of the  lady who conducted my interview was Silvia. At the end of the interview, she advised I  needed a "S.A.E. Special Delivery envelope" which had to be purchased from the Post Office. She also gave me directions on how to get there and advised that I  could go straight back without the need of getting another ticket for appointment explaining that it was only for the envelope to be dropped off.  The service was good considering how busy they were.  But would also Like  to point out  that like other expats, I  found the telephone was either engaged or nobody answered it and after trying to call them for days, I  sent them an "Urgent Email" regarding my loss giving them all my details including mobile telephone number. A guy from the consulate called me back following my Email and advised  me to book my appointment on-line. Like most people I  find their facilities are poor (i.e. no water fountain as they cannot expect people not to drink when it is hot and while they are waiting) and I  heard from other friends that their toilets don't have any baby or disabled facilities. They also have to work in improving their website as it is not "user-friendly".  It is very important to be prepared before appointments and would like to advice everyone to purchase a S.A.E. Special Delivery envelope if a new passport is needed.

Appalling service. Simply put, when you dial the number ALL you get is a machine (IVR) that only answers the questions that the retard that programmed the question "tree" thought was going to be needed. If you need an answer to any other question, different from the retard's imagination then you are stuck and there is NO possibility whatsoever to speak to anyone. Really bad experience. They simply do not care.

I must say that making the appointment online proved quite challenging and getting in touch by phone with somebody at the Consulate nearly impossible (not picking up the phone or the phone being engaged).
The premises are far too small for the amount of public throughput and it gets very hot in there; be prepared to wait for quite a while before it is your turn. I resent the sign saying "No food or drink"; they simply cannot expect people (in particular children) to go without a drink for the hour-and-a-half wait in those hot conditions,  all the more when there's no water fountain. Having said that, I feel that the staff do pretty well given the resources they have and the volume of people.
As far as service is concerned, all the staff, in particular the girl behind the counter, could not have been more helpful, polite and patient, hence the five stars; I was very impressed with the service. What I did witness was a great deal of people arriving without the correct documentation, forms filled out, SAE, etc., which caused some delay and could have easily been avoided by carefully looking at the instructions on the web page prior to the visit to the Consulate.
I don't know, I just drove someone there

I came here to purchase my Swiss Student visa last spring. The process takes awhile and make sure you have your money and all documentation before arriving. The staff is a little cold, but do not let that get in your way. I came to the embassy three times because there were problems with my application. When you write a letter of content on leaving Switzerland upon completion of your studies, you must make sure it is typed and signed. Make sure you have plenty of money in your bank account because the Swiss will want to make sure you have enough money to be in the coutnry. Make sure to have information on where you will be living in Switzerland and have all your documentation from your Swiss school and home university stating you are going to study in Switzerland. The embassy wants to have everything offical and have mutliple copies. I had 4-5 copies of all the documents needed for the application. The Swiss will want to have 3 copies. For photos, you will need 3 or 4 of the same photo,  for the embassy you can take them at any drug store. I took mine at the CVS in Adams Morgan before heading to the embassy. There is seating in the consular area of the embassy. There is a nice video the plays in the waiting area on tourism in Switzerland and there are plenty of travel guides and maps on the countryto take.
I find it ridiculous that you have to spend so much time waiting around but they have no public restrooms and won't let you use the employee restrooms.

When my passport, cash, and camera got stolen last week in Roma, the US embassy staffs took great care of me.  All I had to do was shown my US driver license to prove ID at out side the embassy, the Italian polizia (they speak fluent English) let me entered without any delay.  I did brought my Italian police report, which I had went to Carabinieri at Piazza Venezia because my bag was stolen at the Collsseo and this was the closet polizia station.  I got in, no waiting in the afternoon.  Got onto the embassy computer, reported my story, registered my US passport was stolen.  Pay US$135.  Took a new set of passport pictures (6 pictures)=EU5.  All in 2 hours, I was assured verbally, and emotionally by very understanding US staffs.  I was out with a new emergency passport to come home.  I just had to write this review to say to those staffs at Roma, thanks so much for your help.  I did got home safely and got back to work on time without delay even through US customs.  You guys are the best.
Helpful although perhaps a bit less than they could be. But seems to be relatively well run.

Histoire

L‚ÄôInstitut Italien de Culture de Montr√©al, est situ√© sur l‚Äôavenue Docteur Penfield, au c≈ìur du Golden Square Mile, le quartier de la bourgeoisie montr√©alaise du 19e si√®cle, entre la rue Stanley et la rue Drummond. L‚ÄôInstitut Italien de Culture de Montr√©al occupe les anciennes √©curies d'une prestigieuse villa de fin de si√®cle qui abrite aujourd'hui le Consulat G√©n√©ral d‚ÄôItalie. 

L‚ÄôInstitut organise des activit√©s culturelles, collabore avec les institutions acad√©miques locales, organise des cours de langue et de culture italiennes, pr√©sente des expositions d‚Äôart, des conf√©rences, des films et des projections vid√©os; et donne des informations sur l‚ÄôUnion Europ√©enne, l‚ÄôItalie, ses r√©gions et son patrimoine culturel. De plus, l‚ÄôInstitut offre des opportunit√©s de collaboration culturelle entre les organisations, les italiens et les canadiens afin de faciliter les √©changes dans le domaine th√©√¢tral, musical et cin√©matographique. 
L‚ÄôInstitut offre des informations et un support logistique pour les op√©rateurs publics et priv√©s, italiens et √©trangers, int√©ress√©s par des √©v√©nements culturels italiens au Canada. L‚ÄôInstitut soutient aussi des initiatives bas√©es sur des principes de d√©mocratie, de respect r√©ciproque et de solidarit√© internationale, qui favorisent le dialogue interculturel et multilat√©ral. 

L'IIC de Montr√©al a √©t√© un membre fondateur d‚ÄôEUNIC Canada et l'IIC est souvent impliqu√© dans les √©v√©nements organis√©s par d'autres services culturels des pays europ√©ens actifs au Qu√©bec et dans le reste du Canada. 
Dans le monde,  il y a 89 Instituts Italiens de Culture, soutenus principalement par le minist√®re italien des Affaires √âtrang√®res. Il y en a trois au Canada: √† Toronto, √† Montr√©al et √† Vancouver. L'Institut Italien de Culture de Montr√©al a sous sa juridiction la province du Qu√©bec et les provinces de l‚ÄôEst du Canada et Ottawa. 
Des informations d√©taill√©es sur les activit√©s organis√©es par l'Institut Italien de Culture √† Montr√©al sont disponibles en fran√ßais, en anglais et en italien sur le site web de l'Institute.

Les informations relatives √† les pr√©c√©dentes activit√©s sont accessibles √† travers le portail de recherche. 
Le b√¢timent de l'Institut appartient au gouvernement italien. Les locaux actuels ont une valeur historique et ils appartiennent √©galement au gouvernement italien. L‚ÄôInstitut se trouve √† proximit√© du campus de l'Universit√© de McGill, sur avenue Docteur-Penfield, √† c√¥t√© du Consulat g√©n√©ral d'Italie au c≈ìur du Golden Square Miles de Montr√©al. 

L‚ÄôInstitut a √©t√© fond√© en 1962 par Antonio D‚ÄôAndrea, professeur d‚ÄôItalien, qui avait auparavant √©tabli le d√©partement de langue italienne √† l‚ÄôUniversit√© McGill et avec Dante della Terza, il cr√©a la revue A Yearbook of Italian Studies. 

D‚ÄôAndrea √©tait convaincu que la revue et l‚ÄôInstitut avaient comme objectif principal de cr√©er un pont culturel entre l‚ÄôItalie et le Canada et, en particulier, entre l‚ÄôItalie et la communaut√© francophone et anglophone du Qu√©bec, y compris celle italo-qu√©b√©coise.

reviews.text:
The embassy of Ghana is truly the most inefficient establishment with the worst customer service I have ever experienced. I had mailed in my visa application because the website lacked information about in person meetings. I followed all of the directions on the website and got no feedback about my application. When my trip was approaching I decided to go directly to the embassy because they had not responded to my emails or calls. The man at the front gate treated me like I had personally attacked him. He would not let me in to speak with anyone simply because they were in drop off hours and I wasn't dropping off (they only have drop off and pick up hours). He told me to go home and wait for the visa to be sent to me. He event threatened to call the cops if I didn't leave as I was outside calling family members to get advice.  

My uncle had a friend who worked there search for my information. He could not locate it. Supposedly they were backed up from recent holidays and had a thousand passports. Still that's no excuse for inefficiency and terrible service. The date of my flight came and I had to completely cancel because I had no information on when my documents would be sent to me. If they at least could've returned my passport I could've submitted it in New York for rushed service. Two other people in my family who were also supposed to make the wedding in Ghana sent applications to the DC embassy and have not gotten anything back. This embassy should absolutely be shut down. It's an embarrassment to Washington, D.C., to the United States and the country of Ghana.

Visa requested (single entry, not expedited).  Visa arrived in their office 5/26 (from FedEx tracking), was stamped 6/2 and returned to me on 6/7.  Overall service was fast but communication is nonexistent - no phone number for the consular section and my email went unanswered.  Would be great to have a tracking system for the visa for the perpetually anxious like me.  Or even an evisa like Kenya would make perfect sense!!

K so i sent my passport to them in march just for change of last name, i emailed and called but no answer , sometimes they will pick the phone up and hang up. I sent my husband to NY and they wanted a bribe as usual they claim machines are broken but i knw people who  have received their passports . It took my husband flying to NY to get my passport . I also sent an application for a travel certificate to Washington  DC the money order was cashed  but i never heard from them , Ghana has lost another citizen.  I wonder if the government knows about all these shenanigans .

I will give credit where credit is due. I was super scared about sending our passports to the Embassy after reading the reviews, but we needed the visas so I followed all the directions to a "T" and sent off our applications. I sent the applications overnight on a Thursday and received them back at my doorstep the next Thursday. I was anxious the whole time that they'd get lost or that we would not get them back in time but they were efficient and took less than a week. I guess they are really trying to make some changes in their reliability department, if so...good work.

After reading the many negative reviews here, I was concerned about sending my passport to the Ghana Embassy to obtain a visa for an upcoming business trip.  I need not have been concerned.  The staff called me to clarify an issue on the application, responded promptly to an email, and then mailed my passport (and my husband‚Äôs) back to us with the visas inserted within 24 hours. Everything went very smoothly. (We did pay for rush service, so that may have helped.) My advice: make sure you follow the instructions very carefully. ‚ÄúMultiple entry‚Äù means entering the country more than once, not applying for multiple visas. My husband and I both needed a visa to enter once, and we mistakenly checked the box ‚Äúmultiple entry‚Äù when we should have checked the box for ‚Äúsingle entry‚Äù twice.

Do the employees working over the Consulate know of all the Indian states? Can someone check if the book is updated? If I visit RTA in Australia and if I hand over my Indian Licence, they immediately refer to the book that consists of Indian Licences. They came back saying that my licence was not listed in the book and I ought to get a letter from the Indian Embassy that the Licence was issued in India. When I visit the Embassy, it wants to get a letter from the Licence Issuing Authority in my state in India. My LIA asks why it should be proved as it's given by the state government and if the Central government requires any details, they should contact the state government. When Indian Consulate don't agree to the artefacts issued by one of the states of its country, Indian Consulate, do you really want me to say that I'm a proud Indian?

The consulate instead of throwing the responsibilities to the patrons from every state of India, should take ownership and responsibility in validating any identity instead of behaving like a foreign corporate company.

On ne parle pas de tous les autres d√©fauts dont le syst√®me audio pourris inaudible, le ton du personnel qui n'a jamais du se remettre en question de sa vie, les boulets √† la mentalit√© de bl√©dard parmi les gens qui attendent et qu'on retrouvent toujours dans ce type d'endroit, de la magouille et du copinage qui ont permis √† certains apr√®s nous de passer devant nous (c'est cens√© √™tre par tickets, quand j'arrive je suis num√©ro 54 et je me retrouve avec des num√©ros √† partir de 70...) , bref vraiment un service d'un autre si√®cle, malheureusement encore disponible en 2015 dans ce consulat. 

Je noterais bien 0 si c'√©tait possible mais c'est pas le cas et il n'y a qu'a regarder les notes des autres consulats d'Alg√©rie en France, ou les commentaires sont tout de m√™me plus durs que le mien et y a pas vraiment d'erreur sur la cible, une mentalit√© qui ne change pas, presque culturel et une r√©putation malsaine qui nous colle √† la peau mais on sait √† cause de qui... Je retiendrais ce commentaire post√© par quelqu'un¬†:

Ringrazio l'Ambasciata Italiana a Yerevan, Armenia, per l'assistenza fornitami dal suo staff in occasione dell'incidente motociclistico occorsomi il 13 maggio 2016 nella campagna vicino a Gyumri. In particolare Cinzia (non ricordo il cognome) che ha attivato il molto gentile Console Onorario a Gyumri, Dott. Antonio Montalto che mi ha immediatamente raggiunto nell'ospedale locale dove mi ha assistito nei colloqui con il personale medico e con la polizia locale per risolvere tutti gli aspetti burocratici dai quali sarei uscito con molta fatica. Si √® occupato del trasferimento della mia moto nella sua propriet√† e si √® offerto di ospitarla gratuitamente sino al mio ritorno per prelevarla. Il Console ha organizzato in maniera eccellente il rientro per me e per i miei bagagli, dal viaggio in auto da Gyumri a Yerevan all'assistenza in aeroporto per il volo verso l'Italia. Ancora grazie di cuore.

reviews.text:
One of the slowest Consular Section of Thailand in my life, but they have a lot of people every single day!

All you need is to come there and fill application form (which is free! Locals may ‚Äúhelp‚Äù you for ~100 ‡∏ø, if you need a help, as that is very easy here) in a big building on the left and then you need to stay in a queue which is on the right. You are slowly moving (it would take you about 1.5 hour to move all the queue since the end of the queue till the very beginning) and then they check your documents and if they are correct you are done and welcome to come on a next day.

Do not forget to photocopy your fresh Laos‚Äô visa which costs 5 ‡∏ø (Five Thai Baht) per sheet right there in the building on the left.

It may cost you 400 ‡∏ø for a private car from the Thai border right to the Consular Section, which may be easier/faster, especially if you are not alone. (Or you still may share it with someone.)

Enjoy your Laos meanwhile ;)

JDB ATM--this is what you'll need if you need extra money while stuck in Laos. Many people besides us were walking the streets looking for an ATM that doesn't deny our cards. Ask a tuk tuk driver to bring you to the ATM. Saying international ATM or bank could work too.
Hey JDB or other banks that won't leave us high and dry in this country--set up on the street by this consular office and make a killing. The numerous banks sure aren't taking advantage/helping us out. What a great scare they inflict on a great many people.
I say this because the hotels, tuk tuk rides, restaurants, etc. can drain the money you brought quick, and then you won't have the money you need for what you came for--the visa.
Beware of the people set up outside the consular gates. They'll rip you off. After the waits I've had in Korea that last up to 9 hours, this 1 to 2 hour wait is nothing. 
It sure is exhausting to come out here. I wish they'd just charge us at a local government office.

The place is easy to find. This is where you ask for a visa. Don't forget to bring Thai baht to pay for your visa. Make sure you have all your documents. Submit the paper in the morning only and get your visa on the next working day afternoon.

I'm an American citizen that lives in NYC. I can not believe that Venezuela Public office here in New York City ,with its current social, economical and human right crisis are only OPEN 20 hours a week. Also their phone systems provide no information help or guidance.  
This is obvious of why regular standard facts of life DO NOT FUNCTION under the VENEZUELAN Government Mr. Chavez left behind as an example.

HP CONTESTEN LOS TEL√âFONOS!!!!!
RE - CONTRA - HP

I am a US citizen and I went to the NY Venezuelan consulate to get a tourist visa in October 2015. Everyone was very kind and helpful. I got my visa in the mail within 10 days of submitting the papers.  I have in-laws in Venezuela who have gone to the US embassy many times to apply for a US tourist visa. They are always treated horribly by the US  embassy staff. Its shameful the way they are treated in such a demeaning fashion. To make matters worse, their visa request is always denied for no legitimate reason. Clearly, the staff at the NY Venezuelan  consulate treats the US citizens  far better than the US embassy in Caracas treats Venezuelans. I congratulate the staff at the Venezuelan consulate for taking the higher ground and treating people with respect even when the US does not do so.

wirkliche einwandfreie und kompetente Abwicklung bei der Erteilung eines Arbeitsvisums. Auch Terminw√ºnsche wurden ohne b√ºrokratischen Aufwand ber√ºcksichtigt.

Great! What a relief we have google maps!

Manchester office. This embassy and the helpline are the exact opposite of what the title suggests they are! Appalling service in Manchester. We had to rearrange an appointment twice only to be told I couldn't provide identity and proof to sponsor my partner because I am not his wife! When questioning this all I got was "I'm only the messenger". She had no clue about anything and the support you get from the helping is rubbish! They spoke to me like they couldn't be bothered and didn't really care! All we want is 1 weeks holiday in Greece.....this experience has totally put me off going to Greece in the future which is a shame because I'm sure others will think the same......meaning Greece will loose tourists and money because of incompetence and rude staff! Real let down.

Am I going to be the first person that gives them 5 stars?
Had my passport appointment booked 2 months in advance through their online system - two weeks before the appointment I had to reconfirm my appointment - all good.
Arrived in London, went straight for my photo to be taken at Euro Foto (21 pounds - rip off).
Upon my arrival (the entrance is on the right hand side and ring the bell) the receptionist wrote down my details and was told to wait until the time of my appointment.
At 11 a lovely lady came out and asked me for my papers which I handed over so she had to fill the forms, fingerprints taken and reviewed together all my details before submission. Paid the amount kept the receipt and headed towards the train station.
The passport arrived in less than a month  - you will get a phone call from them.
You dont need an appointment to get your new passport so I nipped at a time of my convenience - In 5 minutes I had my new passport on my hands.
All staff that I faced were helpful and were doing their job right - to my pleasant surprise !  
Maybe I am 1 in 100 but treat people with respect and will treat you with respect.

-Have all the necessary documents with you
-Your photo must be taken from Euro Foto (London W8 6ND)
-Stay positive

The most ridiculous service I've ever had in my life. Totally unprofessional people, rude, arrogant and incapable of carrying out their duties. Sadly they verify most of  the bad stereotypes one has for public employees in Greece . Their electronic system for booking appointments for new passports etc is absolutely ridiculous. Nobody ever answers on the phone .

I recently contacted the UAE Embassy in regards to a local court fraud case in the UAE where a local was pardoned from jail with a Presidential Pardon and a pardon with a promise to pay and settle the debts of the locals which were pardoned. I requested assistance from Embassy for payment as promised by President for payment but have not been assisted or paid as promised by Presidet or Dewan's Office in Abu Dhabi which handles payments of citizen's Debts. These debts of the locals which were promised to be paid by the President of the UAE have not been paid as promised. We can not provide links to recent newspapers articles here due to Google Review Guidelines. Please do a Google search for UAE Pardons during the month of May and June and maybe type in under key words " UAE Pardon 879".

I have waited for around 10 years to be paid and every time I call the Dewan's Office in Abu Dhabi they say that they have not received money from the President to pay the debts of the local prisoners that were released. I have contacted the Embassy in Washington numerous times to resolve this issue and until now they have not paid as promised. More on this can be seen by doing a search for Dubai check Fraud.

I had to give them a 1 star rating because I was awarded a court case win in Dubai Courts,took them for ever to find and arrest this man. Every time he was arrested he was pardoned by the President with a promise to pay of which was never honored. In Islam this is very unislamic to do. The only way one is forgiven is if the victim is compensated and if the victim forgives the other party. To let a criminal go free without paying off the victim is not something God (Allah) will accept on Judgement Day. The UAE Embassy in Washington and Los Angeles have chosen to turn a blind eye to this but I have chose to write a review about this so people see and know the other side of the UAE here in America. For those that are unaware of how things work in the UAE I will briefly highlight them. Every year there are probably 3-4 Presidential Pardons that are issued by the President to pardon locals from prison for various crimes and because one that is found guilty of financial fraud the person freed or freeing them must pay off the debts of the person being freed according to Islamic beliefs (morally this should be done as well) so while an announcement of a pardon being announced with an announcement being made to pay and settle their debts may sound great to those reading this news, the reality of the victims not being paid is not something that ever makes news and hits the media because local news media never questions payments of announcements by the President or government. While there is a media gag and censorship on stuff like this those that believe in God know that you may be able to hide stuff from the media on reporting but those who pray 5 times a day and fast during Ramadan surely know that God (Allah) does see this and will hold them accountable on Judgement Day.

Once this case is resolved and I have been paid I will update my review to more stars but until then 1 star is being generous because an Embassy in the US they should help US Citizens get their money back for what their courts awarded and what their President promised to pay. The UAE Embassy is the representative office for the UAE in America.

Guests at the Embassy of the UAE are welcomed by a soaring atrium with gleaming steel and glass surrounding an open floor plan.  Out back, very pleasant gardens make a great space for a stroll to mingle and network in the most DC of places. It would be inappropriate to describe security measures, but its safe to say you should leave large metal objects at home.

I thought a month in advance would be plenty of time to get a visa to Brazil, but when I heard the consulate had been on strike and there was a backlog, I needed the best possible agency so that I would have every likelihood of getting my visa on time. I had plane tickets purchased and dozens of people counting on me. The excellent representative Maricel in the New York TDS was straight up with me-- she didn't know if she could get it for me on time-- but she made the appointment with the consulate right away during our first phone call and gave me very clear instructions (instructions that I found to be clearer and more accurate than those provided by other visa agencies I looked into). To my tremendous relief the visa arrived at my door via fedex two weeks early. TDS's customer service via email and phone was more than excellent! Though I was scared to mail off my passport I now know whom to trust and I wouldn't hesitate to use TDS again.

Extremely rude service and more than a month of delays on my visa due to confusing information from the people who answered the phones. The marketing manager was exceptionally rude and completely unwilling to address my concerns.
Went there to get help getting a Chinese visa. The staff was very friendly and knowledgeable. I would highly recommend it to anyone that is in need of visa assistance.
A little skeptical at first but world-class service.  Got my Visa back within 2 business days.  Well worth the money - flawless.

reviews.text: Its hard to contact the support team and even I had called them, they don't know anything about what they are saying. Recently, they have changed every application procedure to online but they don't know the fact that only few people will be familiar with that and Immigration New Zealand also maintaining the paper based and online system for the sake of people.  May be they should try to understand the word user friendly.

I am very impressed with High Commission of India, Wellington. I have sent my passport for renewal and I got it in 2 weeks without any issues. If we read their requirements online and send proper documents which is required, there will be no delay or returning of your application. One of my friend have sent their passport for PCC on a Thursday and they have their passport back with PCC on Tuesday. It happened just in one day. If you don't follow the instructions online then there will be issues other there is no issues with their services.

Considering this is the face of India in NZ - I'd expect an excellent and professional service!
Rather than venting my frustration here, I'd like to give a couple of suggestions and these are for sure based on my recent interactions.

1. PLEASE have an active and answerable phone line. It is so hard to get hold of anyone from the office when living outside Wellington and any delays to visa processing WITHOUT a clear update about the application means changing flights etc. involving hundreds of dollars. I do understand that the website cleverly says, please book your travel accordingly - but sometimes you are bound to tight timelines and it helps getting some regular updates.

2. Increase working hours - only 3 hours a day is very short

3. Make the website a bit more clear and logical - You miss one little detail and the processing times are out the door.

4. Please employ friendly staff with good understanding of the services - Very unstructured and rude customer service (at least my experience)

Nice and excellent service and they respond promptly.I've applied for renewal passport, they respond so quickly on my special request. I can see the improvement in IND governance, should give credit to BJP as well. keep it up team. 

Cheers,
KK

There is no respect for anyone in their office and they still believe here is India,considering you are a tourist and want to travel and generate some income for locals!
Their website also gives you wrong information and customer service never answers the phone!
The operator in the embassy could be more friendly and cooperative. My question was not answered and her advice was not useful.

reviews.text: Passport services for American citizens are very inconvenient and poor. It is nearly impossible to reach anyone by telephone even during supposed office hours. The staff seems to take a 2 hour lunch, which makes it inconvenient for people traveling from long distances around Sweden to return with cash when credit cards are not accepted as promised. Had to return with cash in afternoon, missed train home and had to buy a new expensive ticket. Could have avoided this if they had waited an extra 15 minutes before lunching.They couldn't have cared less. It is difficult to change appointment times on the website. They never answered a single email except with a very unhelpful form letter. I have written the Chief in the past but have never gotten a response. This is in direct contrast to other consulates and embassies around the world who are normally quite flexible and helpful and I have worked with several. There IS a better way to run a consulate and embassy. Please go get some training in TQM, Total Quality Management for service providers!

Telephone contact very poor. Tried since 2012.

reviews.text: They never answer the phone. Even while there, i could hear the phones being unanswered. I needed my visa and didn't know what i had to do. A friend from the netherlands told me what the consulate there asked him so i took those documents. The person in charge of visas wasn't there on wednesday so they asked me to go thursday from 9 to eleven. I had to miss my class on thursday morning to come and find that the person wasn't here, again. I waited for 3 hours, everyone said something different about the where abouts of this person. I feel very disrespected for they have wasted my time.

Question is must everything about Nigeria be backwards?
The amount of time I have spent trying to get through to the embassy is unreal.
Everything about this commission is a joke. I do not even know where to start from. From the time when I wanted more information as to how to go about renewing my passport online. it took me a whole 3 days to get through to them.
When I eventually got through to them the woman who answered to me sounded so miserable and was not friendly at all. A bit helpful yes, but definitely not the happiest person.
When I decided to start my online application the process wasn't too bad however when it was time to pay they were doing the most. 
The payment process wasn't straight forward which resulted to me not being able to pay because there was just a problem with everything.
I decided to give them a call again and for hours now I have been on the phone trying to get through to them and its just horrible.
The customer service is quite incompetent as well.
They need to sort this situation out because what would be point of boasting about being the largest country in Africa and be this inadequate.
This is unacceptable!!!

I have been trying to pay for a re-issue of an e-passport  on line for three days unsuccessful.The procedures,forms   ,website  and   systems are cumbersome and not fit for purpose. Postal Orders  etc 2016 ! Will  phone and visit the high comission tomorrow to continue wasting my time.
Anthony Anumba

It's shameful for Nigeria to turn her attention away from the predicament their citizens are passing through all in the process of getting ppt or visas from the high commission. I travelled from far away Essex to stay on the queue for 2 hrs in bad weather, it's shameful for Nigeria

Very disorganised, HOWEVER, I must say getting my passport from submitting to receiving was fairly straight forward and didn't take that long at all. Was even easier than doing it in Ikoyi, Lagos. However, they really need to get themselves organised, they tell you to bring a picture, but snap a picture of you, they make you waste your time with a postal order (a bit dated and pointless if you ask me). Nigeria is a great nation, supposedly the powerhouse of Africa, this is not reflected in the High Commission. Whats worse is 5-year passports is pretty much a money making scheme, most countries do 10-year passports. Not great to have to go through this every 5-years. I'll give it a 3-star for speed I guess. They really need to make the passport renewal an online process!
